author: Perry Williams
title: Crown Resorts avoids Las Vegas low rollers
text:
Crown Resorts will target high-end gamblers and tourists with its planned Alon resort in Las Vegas, due to open in 2018. iStock Share on twitter by Perry Williams Crown Resorts plans to target high roller and VIP customers at its $4 billion Alon casino in Las Vegas saying there was little point focusing on the mass market given the intense rivalry on the strip for that segment of customers.
James Packer, who owns 50 per cent of Crown, has spent the last 12 months planning a return to Vegas after losing almost $US2 billion ($2.76 billion) during the 2008 credit crisis from poorly timed North America casino investments.
Details of the 1100-room complex have been sketchy but Crown's strategy and design chief, Todd Nisbet, said it had recently won development and planning approvals from Nevada authorities and was now turning its attention to the design concepts of the complex.
"Our Alon project in Vegas is a different proposition given what our market positioning is there," Mr Nisbet told Fairfax Media. "There's already a lot of mass market offerings in Vegas. So I think any response we have in terms of the type of project and its positioning needs to be determined in the backdrop of what else is in the market. It's more on the luxury end."
The pitch to target the luxury end of the market echoes comments made by Alon's recently hired entertainment tsar, Jesse Waits, who said the resort will target an intimate entertainment offering as punters begin to tire of the mass-market club scene.
Crown hopes to break ground on the new project in the first half of 2016 although Mr Nisbet said a funding deal to finance the facility would need to be agreed first.
Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse are arranging financing for the Alon joint venture, with Crown expected to sell down some of its 74 per cent stake in the project. A US debt deal could also be announced within the next few months.
"We're proceeding with a detailed design and we're currently working through our financing and the balance of our detailed construction permits. Its part of the normal pre construction process," said Mr Nisbet. "With a little bit of luck we hope to break ground on the project in the first half of next year. And that means we will be working through although we won't start construction until we have a fully financed project."
After stepping down as Crown chairman in August for a new executive director role, Mr Packer said he would focus on developing the Vegas project along with its planned Sydney casino at Barangaroo.
Newly installed Crown chairman Rob Rankin admitted in August that Crown had a bulging pipeline but said all of its developments including Las Vegas, Sydney and potentially Japan must meet strict investment criteria.
 "We're not running around trying to develop dozens of projects," said Mr Rankin at the time. "I think our main focus is Sydney, Vegas and Melbourne, but in the right circumstances we would stretch for Japan as well in partnership with Melco Crown. As a longer-term proposition, Japan excites us."
Crown on Monday also revealed details of a new $1.5 billion six-star Melbourne hotel, connected to its existing Melbourne casino complex, which it hopes to open by late 2019 .
